titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Kenneth C. Smithburn Papers FA040

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-04 00:21:16 -0400.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Rockefeller Foundation. Division of Medicine and Public Health

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in four series:

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Kenneth C. Smithburn was born October 19, 1904, in Noblesville, Indiana. He received the B.S. (1926) and the M.D. (1928) degrees from Indiana University.

From 1930-1938, Smithburn was a staff member of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research in New York (later known as The Rockefeller University). In 1939, he joined the Yellow Fever Research Institute, Entebbe, Uganda, becoming director in 1946, a post he held until 1948. In 1953 he organized and directed a unit for research in Johannesburg, South Africa, on arthropod-borne viruses under the joint sponsorship of the Rockefeller Foundation, the South African Institute for Medical Research, and the Poliomyelitis Research Foundation. He remained there until 1959 when he retired.

Smithburn was appointed to the Hemorrhagic Fever Commission (1952-1954), and the Virus and Rickettsial Disease Commission (1953). He was a member of the following organizations: American Association of Immunologists, American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene, and the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene. He was a fellow of the New York Academy of Sciences and an honorary member of the British Medical Association.

Smithburn was a prolific writer publishing both individually and jointly over ninety monographs. Subjects covered in these publications include: meningococcal disease, meningitis, anemias, experimental tuberculosis, epidemiology of yellow fever, neurotropic viruses isolated in Africa, immunological relationships between viruses, and antiviral immunity surveys.
Kenneth C. Smithburn died in Indianapolis, Indiana, on November 23, 1973.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Kenneth C. Smithburn papers document the career of research scientist Kenneth C. Smithburn in the identification and isolation of viruses, particularly the Yellow Fever virus in Africa. The papers also document more broadly the Foundation's interest in public health through the International Health Division and its successor, the Division of Medicine and Public Health. The papers span the years 1922 to 1974, with the bulk falling between the years 1938 through 1959.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted are noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Candace Shuluk completed processing of this collection in December 1995. Processing Level 3: Standard Processing. All material is available in acid free manuscript boxes and folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 1, Subject Files, contains Smithburn's professional correspondence and experimental data arranged in the order in which they were received. Thus, within these files, both unique and routine materials are intermingled. Information about Smithburn's appointment in 1938 to the Yellow Fever Unit in Entebbe is found in correspondence with the Rockefeller Foundation in folder 60. Correspondence with colleagues Alec Haddow (1943-1964), Stuart Kitchen (1946-1964), and Paul Maurice Weinbren (1955-1959) contain ongoing discussions of experiments and scientific findings in Entebbe following his departure in 1948. Correspondence with George Strode in 1947, located in folder 67, reveals Smithburn's concern about the impending transfer of the Entebbe Unit to London control and his desire to return to the States. A brief history of the Entebbe Unit, written by Smithburn, is located in folder 54.

Also present in Series 1 are reports, memoranda and correspondence (folders 12, 14-16) relating to work done on behalf of the Army Epidemiological Board with Hemorrhagic Fever in Japan and Korea from 1952 to 1953. There is extensive correspondence with Robert Kokernot (1955-1973), primarily personal in nature, with early letters describing laboratory experiments in Johannesburg, South Africa. Smithburn's correspondence with the Rockefeller Foundation is of a routine nature and concerns reimbursements for supplies, salary and retirement, housing, insurance, and other personal matters.

Scientific data and experiment files contain information on a variety of viruses, their carriers, and protocols used. A 1953 letter between Smithburn and John Craig in folder 28, discusses linkages between Japanese B Encephalitis and the arthropod-borne viruses. An epidemic similar in nature to Chikungunya disease is described in a report located in folder 4. There are nine letters from Albert B. Sabin relating to experiments with the dengue and sandfly fever viruses.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: In Series 1, the files are arranged alphabetically by name and subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 2, Professional Diaries, contains Smithburn's personal copies (handwritten) of the diaries he kept on a daily basis while in Africa. Typed copies of the diaries and monthly summaries were sent to the Rockefeller Foundation on a regular basis. These are located in the Rockefeller Foundation Archives, Record Group 12.1, Box 56. There is a gap for the period from 1949 through most of 1953, during which time Smithburn worked in the New York offices.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: In Series 2, diaries are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 3, Personal Papers, contains correspondence with friends and colleagues following Smithburn's retirement in 1959. A concise and thorough documentation of Smithburn's illness is contained in folder 133.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials in Series 3 are arranged alphabetically by type of material and thereunder alphabetically or chronologically.

did.unittitle: Emphysema - Papers Related to the Treatment of

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 4, Printed Materials, contains two bound volumes of Smithburn's published works. There is also a loose monograph not included in the bound volumes, entitled "Studies on Arthropod-Borne Viruses of Tongaland."

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: In Series 4, printed materials are arranged chronologically.
